Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge correctly apply the physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: The applicant was absent for all but 117 days in the four-year period preceding the application.
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge did not err in applying the physical presence test.
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of the physical presence test by the Citizenship Judge
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the citizenship judge
Review_Standard: Standard of correctness or reasonableness (implied by appeal context)
Evidence_Used: Record of applicant's physical presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Requirement of 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of applicant's residency and absences
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the citizenship judge’s decision and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: An applicant must have been physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years preceding the application.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented days of physical presence
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Harm_Assessment: No harm found due to lawful application of residency requirements
Cause_Description: Applicant's failure to meet residency requirements due to insufficient physical presence days
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed based on the record before the citizenship judge
Evidence_Assessment: The judge applied the physical presence test in accordance with statutory requirements
Decision_Rationale: The applicant did not meet the statutory physical presence requirement; the judge correctly applied the law
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation and application of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
